Catalonia has been shaken by the turbulent aftermath of a Supreme Court decision to jail the Spanish region‚Äôs separatist leaders. While the head of the court called the judgment the most important in the history of the country‚Äôs democracy, one separatist MP branded it the gravest aggression against Catalonia since the early days of fascism. ‚Å†
‚Å†
On Monday, the Supreme Court sentenced Oriol Junqueras, the former deputy leader of Catalonia‚Äôs regional government, to 13 years in prison for sedition and misuse of public funds, over an illegal 2017 referendum on independence. It sentenced eight others to between nine and 12 years. ‚Å†
‚Å†
In response, thousands of protesters took to the streets, cutting off roads and railway lines and causing chaos at Barcelona airport, where on Monday more than 100 flights were cancelled and more than 70 people injured in clashes between demonstrators and police. ‚Å†

Queen Elizabeth II delivered her 65th Queen's Speech to parliament in the House of Lords today. ‚Å†
‚Å†
In the run-up to a pivotal EU leaders‚Äô summit this week, Boris Johnson hopes to secure agreement with Brussels on a Brexit deal. The monarch confirmed that the prime minister would then seek to table a withdrawal agreement bill to enact it into law.‚Å†
‚Å†
The Queen‚Äôs Speech included 26 pieces of legislation that in effect set out the contents of a potential Conservative party manifesto; since Mr Johnson has no House of Commons majority, he cannot expect to put any of his proposals into law in this parliament.‚Å†

KPMG has breathed new life into the phrase ‚Äúpetty bean-counters‚Äù with a recent decision to cancel work mobile phones for hundreds of junior and back-office employees.‚Å†
‚Å†
The move by the British arm of the Big Four accountancy firm is part of a larger cost-cutting drive that will include letting go about 200 secretaries and personal assistants and telling partners to file their own expenses claims.‚Å†
‚Å†
Few people would take issue with the need to keep down costs right now. Economic gloom is spreading worldwide, with Europe and the UK looking particularly vulnerable. ‚Å†
‚Å†
When Charlie Ergen was chief executive of Dish, the US television provider took pride in being known as ‚Äúmeanest company in America‚Äù. It refused to reimburse tips of more than 17% on restaurant meals and required employees to share hotel rooms on business trips.‚Å†
‚Å†
But Andr√© Spicer, a professor of organisational behaviour at Cass Business School, warns that such symbolic cost-cutting can easily do more harm than good. ‚ÄúA lot of the time, they undermine the purposes of what they are trying to achieve. People are much more attached to small things than large things,‚Äù he says.‚Å†

Ethiopian prime minister Abiy Ahmed has won this year‚Äôs Nobel Peace Prize for ending the 20-year conflict between his east African country and neighbouring Eritrea.‚Å†
‚Å†
The Norwegian Nobel Committee praised ‚Äúhis efforts to achieve peace and international co-operation, and in particular for his decisive initiative to resolve the border conflict with neighbouring Eritrea‚Äù.‚Å†

The UK‚Äôs most counterfeited banknote has been overhauled by the central bank to make it harder to forge.‚Å†
‚Å†
The Bank of England unveiled on Thursday the new-look ¬£20 note, which has two windows and a two-colour metallic hologram that will make it harder to counterfeit. According to the central bank, it is now ‚Äúthe most secure Bank of England note yet‚Äù.‚Å†
‚Å†
There are 2bn ¬£20 notes in circulation, according to the BoE, out of a total of 3.8bn banknotes. Faked ¬£20s accounted for nine out of 10 counterfeit notes discovered by the central bank last year.‚Å†
‚Å†

The humble leader is an age-old concept. Only recently, though, has the FT‚Äôs Andrew Hill noticed how many chief executives and politicians have started boasting about how humble they are.‚Å†
‚Å†
Hardly a week goes by without some high-profile leader somewhere publicly declaring that they have been ‚Äúhumbled‚Äù by a promotion, a prize, a successful project, a runaway product launch, or a show of employee or customer support that they themselves orchestrated.‚Å†
‚Å†
One problem is that humility is not as simple as being modest and keeping a low profile. ‚ÄúThe most valuable player (MVP) of a winning team who thanks her teammates but truly believes that the winning outcome of the game was due solely to her contributions would be displaying modesty but lacking humility,‚Äù one 2005 paper entitled ‚ÄúBringing humility to leadership‚Äù explained.‚Å†
‚Å†
Truly humble leaders must instead show that they accept their strengths and weaknesses and that they are willing to ask and use help from others, this paper suggested.‚Å†

Donald Trump is facing the most dangerous crisis of his presidency after becoming only the fourth US president to face an impeachment inquiry in the House of Representatives. After a July 25th call with the newly elected president of Ukraine, in which he urged Volodymyr Zelensky to investigate former vice-president Joe Biden and his son, Trump has denied impropriety and rejected suggestions that he withheld hundreds of millions of dollars in military aid to Ukraine to pressure its president into co-operating. 
Over the next few months, six committees in the Democratically-controlled House will pursue an investigation that many believe will result in impeachment of the US president. 
So you can be prepared to understand the flow of upcoming news about the impeachment inquiry, the FT has put together a guide to the most important dates and players in this inquiry. üëâ

Boris Johnson's decision to suspend parliament for five weeks and his advice to the Queen was unlawful, the Supreme Court has ruled.‚Å†
‚Å†
The ruling means parliament can be recalled as if it had always been sitting. The president of the Supreme Court, Lady Hale, said: ‚ÄòThe prorogation was void and of no effect. Parliament has not been prorogued...The effect on the function of our democracy was extreme.‚Äô‚Å†
‚Å†
She added that the prorogation stopped parliament from scrutinising the executive and a number of bills were lost due to the shutdown.‚Å†
‚Å†
Apart from the immediate political damage of the ruling, the UK PM now faces the problem that he may struggle to again use prorogation as a tool to sideline MPs if he decides to push for a no-deal Brexit on October 31.‚Å†

As you read this sentence, your brain is telling your diaphragm to contract, your ribs to expand, air is passing through your trachea ‚Äî you are breathing. Air is essential to human life, and yet the air we breathe can also be a source of great harm. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Globally, some seven million deaths each year are linked to the effects of air pollution, according to the World Health Organization, making it the biggest environmental killer. Pollution kills more people than car accidents, diabetes or dementia. ‚Å†
‚Å†
But how bad, really, is the air we breathe? What does air pollution, often presented in abstract statistics, feel like in daily life? Can people in cities wrest any control over the level of pollution they experience? ‚Å†
‚Å†
To answer these questions, the FT asked correspondents in five cities ‚Äî Beijing, Lagos, London, New York and S√£o Paulo ‚Äî to carry a personal pollution monitor for one to two weeks and record the results. ‚Å†

These are skulls of former monks at Vatopedi‚Äôs cemetery, on Mount Athos in Greece. More than 1,000 male pilgrims are granted daily entry visas to the peninsula, which has 20 monasteries; Russia's President Vladimir Putin first visited in 2005.

Since Putin came to power 20 years ago, Russian Orthodoxy has risen in status: tens of thousands of churches have been built; oligarchs have sponsored church charities; and Putin has regularly ‚Äî and publicly ‚Äî sought the advice of church elders in matters spiritual and profane.

He has used religion to highlight divisions between Russia and the supposedly amoral west, and to elevate the idea of the ‚ÄúRussian world‚Äù, a sort of spiritual dominion bringing together Russian-speaking former Soviet citizens, that has been promoted by the church and the state.

The US yield curve inverted this week for the first time since 2007, a bad omen that has preceded every recession in the country since the second world war and a move that rattled financial markets across the globe. Here's why: üî∏üî∏üî∏
The yield curve is essentially a reflection of the distilled wisdom of millions of investors ‚Äî from individual savers to money managers on Wall Street. Although seemingly obscure, it enjoys a cult following among many investors as the leading market forecaster of recessions. Normally, countries should pay less to borrow money for shorter time periods. When this relationship flips, it has historically been a warning of economic downturns to come. 
Now, experts are worried that the countdown to the next recession may have just begun. 
For more on what could happen next and what the trade war has to do with it, click the link in our bio.

Here's some grim news: unexpectedly high levels of microplastics have been found in fresh snow in some of the world's most isolated areas. Samples from remote Arctic and Alpine areas contained thousands of particles per litre ‚Äî underlining the extent of potentially toxic contamination in the earth‚Äôs atmosphere.
üîπ
Scientists are just beginning to investigate the routes plastics take to end up in snow. Some come from sources on land, from paint particles to tiny fragments of rubber from car tyres that wear down. Some of these particles find their way into the sea, where they are broken up by waves and ultraviolet radiation before being swept up into the atmosphere. The microplastics are then captured from the air during cloud formation, when particles act as a nucleus around which supercooled droplets can condense, and as snowflakes drift to earth.

For more on how man-made materials wound up in fresh snow, click the link in our bio.
üîπ

üö® Temperatures are rising, the glaciers of the Himalayas are melting ‚Äî and here‚Äôs why this is particularly significant:  because the area provides water for about 800m people across Asia. üö®

A forthcoming study surveyed decades of satellite data and found that the glaciers have been losing the equivalent of 50cm of ice vertically each year since 2000, melting twice as fast as they were during the 1975 to 2000 period. 
Several factors contribute to melting in the Himalayas, including settled soot and changing precipitation factors. However, the new study suggests that temperature is the single biggest factor that drives the rate of melting, underscoring the impact of climate change on an area that is a critical source of water supply for India and China.
üî∏
The research comes as global carbon dioxide emissions hit a record high last year, and as the earth‚Äôs average temperature has warmed about 1C compared with pre-industrial times.
üî∏

As the world recovers from the Great Recession, we are learning that unemployment statistics can hide a lot of pain in a labour market.

US unemployment returned to its pre-crisis level in late 2016, but it took another year for U6 to recede. The rate at which 25 to 54-year-olds participate in the labour market, another metric of distress, is only now beginning to return to pre-recession levels.

The US is not the only country to have a hidden hangover. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

It's been 30 years since the Tiananmen Square massacre, and here people take part in a candlelight vigil at Victoria Park on June 4, 2019 in Hong Kong.

As many as 180,000 people were expected to attend the vigil to mark the anniversary. Commemorations took place in cities around the world on June 4 to remember those who died when Chinese troops cracked down on pro-democracy protesters. The People's Liberation Army opened fire and killed hundreds or thousands of protesters in Beijing after students and workers gathered in Tiananmen Square for weeks to call for greater political freedom. No one knows for sure how many people were killed as China continues to censor any coverage or discussion of the event that takes place during the anniversary.

Tap the link in our bio to read a story from the FT's James Kynge, who covered Tiananmen Square as a young Reuters journalist. He tried to trace its legacy and what it means for China today.

The farmers who produce the coffee you drink get just 1p from a ¬£2.50 brew ‚Äì pennies in US dollars. So why is your morning brew so expensive?

That's because in an everyday ¬£2.50 brew, the coffee itself accounts for just 4% of the cost, or about 10p, while rent, labour and tax make up three-quarters of the overall price, according to consultancy firm Allegra Strategies. Just a fraction of that actually gets back to farmers.

Police said they had arrested 220 people after black-clad youths hurling bricks and other missiles confronted security forces firing tear gas and stun grenades before the start of a big march across southern Paris.

This is the moment the steeple of the Notre-Dame cathedral collapsed as a fire ravaged the landmark in central Paris.

One of the world‚Äôs best known and most visited monuments, Notre-Dame was devastated by fire on Monday evening in a cultural catastrophe with few precedents in peacetime. Some passers-by were in tears at the sight of the blazing cathedral. ‚ÄúI feel as though I‚Äôve been murdered,‚Äù said one Paris resident returning to her flat after seeing the fire.

More than an hour after the fire erupted, firefighters on at least one side of the building seemed unable even to reach the blaze. On the south side of Notre-Dame a lone firefighter sprayed water from a vehicle-mounted ladder towards the roof, but the water did not come close to reaching the blaze. Four hundred firefighters were deployed.

Tap the link in our bio to read the latest from our correspondents in Paris.

We've found evidence of huge fraud in Congo's election results that are set to provide the first change of power since Joseph Kabila took over the presidency almost 18 years ago. 
Our analysis of two separate collections of voting data contradicts claims from authorities that rival contender Felix Tshisekedi won the historic vote. According to a trove of election data seen by the FT and representing 86% of total votes cast across the country, Martin Fayulu won 59.4% of the vote. Rival opposition candidate Mr Tshisekedi, who was declared the surprise winner last week, finished second with 19%, according to this set of data.

A US study has claimed that the more money is spent on a wedding, the less likely the marriage is to last. And weddings have become ferociously expensive üë∞ The FT‚Äôs John Gapper writes: ‚ÄòAttaching the word ‚Äúwedding‚Äù to an object mysteriously seems to put the price up fivefold. The average cost of a US wedding dress last year was $1,500 and the average wedding cake cost $540. It is not a mystery, really. Selling bespoke goods and services to panicked people who want to demonstrate their love in material form and are up against a deadline is very lucrative.
‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢
The expansion of social media means that everyone can now see photographs of the wedding ‚Äî and engagement party, and every other preparatory event ‚Äî which raises the stakes. My Instagram feed is full of portmanteau hashtags of happy couples in glamorous spots. ‚ÄúIt is not sufficient merely to possess wealth or power. FT Photo Diary üì∏: A crab is seen chasing a newborn green turtle after it was released at a beach last week on Thameehla Island. 
Peril plagues the young life of a baby turtle in Myanmar; if the crabs don't get them before they scramble from the beach to the sea, poachers or fishing trawlers may do ‚Äì while habitat destruction also decimates their numbers. 
Myanmar's waters boast five of the world's seven sea turtle species, including the critically endangered hawksbill, the endangered green turtle as well as the olive ridley, leatherback and loggerhead turtles, all listed as vulnerable.

FT Photo Diary üì∏: Scenic war games ‚Äì Explosives planted by Norwegian Naval Explosive Ordnance Disposal are triggered to clear the beaches of obstacles and enemy mines, during an Intelligence Surveillance and Reconnaissance demonstration, as part of the NATO exercise Trident Juncture 2018, in Byneset near Trondheim, Norway, October 30, 2018. 
Trident Juncture 2018, is a NATO-led military exercise held in Norway from 25 October to 7 November 2018. The exercise is the largest of its kind in Norway since the 1980s. Around 50,000 participants from NATO and partner countries, some 250 aircraft, 65 ships and up to 10,000 vehicles take part in the exercise. The main goal of Trident Juncture is allegedly to train the NATO Response Force and to test the alliance's defence capability.

The world‚Äôs recycling system has stopped working. Since the introduction of household recycling in the 1980s, it has been promoted as the environmental answer to humanity‚Äôs growing amounts of rubbish. It has also developed into a $200bn industry globally, according to the Bureau of International Recycling. 
But this year, all that changed, and now the very purpose of recycling has been thrown into question.

Watch our Story to see how China‚Äôs refusal to become the west‚Äôs dumping ground is forcing the world to face up to a waste crisis.

The nebula is classified as both a reflection nebula as it is reflecting the light of a nearby star and as an emission nebula as it releases hydrogen-alpha radiation. Both effects are caused by the gigantic star Gamma Cassiopeiae. The radiation of this star is also slowly causing the nebula to dissipate.

City pollution is killing residents ‚Äì dirty air accounts for the premature deaths of people in London, New York, Paris and Beijing.

Exposure to fine particles in polluted air contributes to 7m premature deaths worldwide a year, often through heart disease, stroke or lung cancer, estimates the World Health Organisation. That‚Äôs about the same as the toll from tobacco, or 15 times recent annual deaths from war and homicides combined.

It took three weeks after the Lehman Brothers collapse for equities to sell off in full force. When they did, this was the FT front page the next day ‚Äì on Oct. 7, 2008, exactly 10 years ago today.

It was tempting to call it a "crash" ‚Äì and there was an internal debate at the FT about whether to so ‚Äì but editors decided not to call it that... yet.

Amazon was already beating many of its rivals on pay before the decision to raise its minimum wage in the US to $15 per hour.

Jeff Bezos, Amazon's chief executive, said the company had ‚Äúlistened‚Äù to its critics as he announced the new wage floors on Tuesday ‚Äî $15 per hour in the US and ¬£9.50 in the UK, with a higher ¬£10.50 rate in London. Anthony Chukumba, analyst at Loop Capital Markets, estimated the higher wage would add between $900m and $1.8bn in annualised incremental costs in the US. That would at most amount to less than 1% of the $235bn in revenue Wall Street analysts are forecasting for this year.

About 250,000 regular employees, as well as more than 100,000 seasonal workers hired for the holiday shopping season, would benefit in the US, the company said. In the UK, the raises benefit about 17,000 employees and 20,000 temporary staff. Amazon employs more than 575,000 worldwide.

Nine days after reports of a bailout sent the market higher, it all came crashing back down to earth. This was our front page on this day, 10 years ago.

Democracy asserted itself a day earlier and markets howled. The House of Representatives voted down the $700bn bailout. On both sides of the aisle, lawmakers proved far more reluctant to back the rescue than their leaders had expected. 
The minute after the bill failed saw the heaviest midday volume in history. By day‚Äôs end, the Dow Jones Industrial Average had fallen by a record (and very memorable) 777 points. The total fall in US market cap came to far more than the $700bn the administration had wanted to spend on rescuing banks.

This might be the moment that changed the course of Brett Kavanaugh's nomination to the Supreme Court.

Jeff Flake, an Arizona Republican, had previously vowed to back Kavanaugh, but changed his position after he was dramatically confronted in a US Senate elevator by two women who said they were the victims of sexual assault. 
Kavanaugh's nomination still advanced through a committee, but Flake made his vote was contingent on giving the FBI one week to investigate the allegations of sexual assault made against the judge, who was nominated by US President Donald Trump and submitted for Senate approval. He still faces a vote before the full Senate, expected late next week.

Call it Stratford-near-Fuzhou: China is building its own piece of Stratford-upon-Avon ‚Äì complete with copies of houses where William Shakespeare lived.

It's the latest replica project after its replicas of Paris‚Äôs Eiffel Tower, London‚Äôs Tower Bridge and a cowboy-chic version of Jackson Hole in Wyoming. But mindful that the Chinese replica of Tower Bridge ‚Äúimproved‚Äù upon the original by building four towers instead of two to accommodate a multi-lane highway, the Shakespeare Birthplace Trust is insisting on authenticity.

The contract with Fuzhou, in the southern province of Jiangxi, promises an undisclosed fee to the Trust for help in creating replicas of the two houses that are as faithful to the originals as possible. This includes providing ‚Äúexpert guidance on traditional building methods and materials‚Äù, according to a statement from the Trust.

For first time in decades, young people in the UK are less likely to live longer than their parents, according to new official data.

Until 2011, the UK ‚Äî in common with most of the developed world ‚Äî had made steady gains in life expectancy for many decades, helped at first by the introduction of childhood immunisations and later by the decline in smoking and advances in treating health conditions for older people. 
The Office for National Statistics said the main factor was the unusually high number of deaths in the three-year period from 2015-2017: in 2015, the year-on-year rise in deaths in England and Wales was the biggest since 1968.

Many government critics have blamed this spike in deaths on the effects of austerity policies, which have strained hospitals and forced many local authorities to restrict eligibility for social care.

However, there is no clear evidence that austerity is to blame. Researchers point to poor lifestyle and widespread obesity, and to outbreaks of seasonal flu. Earlier gains from advances in treating cardiovascular disease ‚Äî especially important in the UK ‚Äî have also been tailing off.

The dotted line seen here is more than just the line between Ireland and the UK. It's become one of the most contentious issues in the debate over how Britain will leave the EU ‚Äì and what that exit means for the the future of the Irish border.

But it's bigger than a question of trade and travel ‚Äì for the people who live there. We explored the real impact of Brexit on the border in a short film featuring actor Stephen Rea, with a poem written by Clare Dwyer Hogg. It begins: "Jacob Rees-Mogg, you're right. In the decade since the financial crisis, China‚Äôs export sector has proved remarkably resilient ‚Äì and it has made big gains in technology. 
As the trade war between the US and China grows, officials in Donald Trump‚Äôs administration have focused on Chinese advances in high-tech areas such as artificial intelligence and robotics to justify their use of tariffs. 
Yet in the short term, the bigger threat to industry in the US and other developed economies comes from the rapid increase in Chinese exports of medium-level technology, such as vehicles and their parts, electrical machinery and the sort of construction machinery that Sany produces. It is in products such as these ‚Äî rather than high-tech goods ‚Äî that Chinese companies are swiftly winning market share.

This is what the FT front page looked like on this day in 2008 ‚Äì the day after Lehman Brothers collapsed. We called it "Banking's Black Monday". Investors had assumed that there would be a rescue for Lehman, as there had been for Bear Stearns earlier in the year. Even if not, Lehman and its creditors and investors had had months to prepare for what had just happened. Some people we talked to that day were panicking; but many assumed that precautions had been taken, and damage would be limited. They were wrong.

In September 2008, the FT‚Äôs John Gapper wrote that the US government should resist saving Lehman Brothers. Within days, his advice (and that of others) was taken, triggering a postwar financial crisis and unleashing economic and social damage that still endures today. ‚Ä¢

Here are his thoughts on the column 10 years later: 'No bank should have had the right to expect, or to demand, salvation. 
But none of this, nor my self-justification in 2010 that letting Lehman fold had been ‚Äúa gamble worth taking‚Äù, gets me off the hook. My argument was about more than the fate of one foolish bank. It covered all of Wall Street‚Äôs investment banks and trading institutions apart from retail banks. 
What strikes me now is less my wrongness than my naivety. I hoped and believed ‚Äî implausibly, given that barriers between commercial and investment banks had been weakened by changes in US law and mergers ‚Äî that investment banks were still small and separate enough to collapse without precipitating a crisis.' California is due to become the first US state to impose a quota for the inclusion of women on the boards of public companies headquartered there.

It would be the first government-mandated quota for women on company boards in the US, but there is precedent for doing so in European countries. Norway, Iceland, Finland and Sweden all have government-mandated quotas for the number of women on boards. A 2016 study found that quotas are effective in increasing female representation on boards. The US ranked 17th globally for its percentage of women on boards in 2015, according to Credit Suisse.

What does the revamped Nafta deal mean for carmakers? There are two important rules that will affect car manufacturing in the agreement the US reached with Mexico over new trade rules that will update the North American Free Trade Agreement.

The first is that 75% of the parts used in US and Mexican-assembled vehicles must come from within North America. This is higher than the current level of 62.5%, but far lower than the 85% figure that the US originally pursued in the talks. 
The second rule is between 40 and 45%of the content that goes into the vehicles must be made by workers earning $16 an hour or more.

Despite ongoing international negotiations aimed at easing tensions on the Korean peninsula, the Democratic People's Republic of Korea remains the most isolated and secretive nation on earth. 
Since it's formation in 1948 the country has been led by the Kim dynasty, a three-generation lineage of North Korean leadership descended from the country's first leader, Kim Il-sung followed by Kim Jong-il and grandson and current leader, Kim Jong-un. Although major hostilities ceased with the signing of the Armistice in 1953, the two Koreas have remained technically at war and the demilitarised zone along the border continues to be the most fortified border in the world.

London‚Äôs air often appears clear to the naked eye, but the city has suffered from illegal levels of air pollution since 2010, with particularly dangerous levels of nitrogen dioxide, which comes mainly from diesel vehicles. This summer‚Äôs unusually hot and sunny weather has caused surges in ozone ‚Äî produced when sunlight reacts with nitrogen dioxide ‚Äî that have prompted multiple pollution warnings. 
While cities such as Beijing or New Delhi usually attract more headlines, the stubborn air pollution in London shows just how intractable the problem can be. Under some measures, such as extremely small air particles, the smog in New Delhi and Beijing is much worse than London. But in terms of nitrogen dioxide, which inflames lungs and is linked to shorter life expectancy, London is nearly as bad as the Chinese and Indian capitals ‚Äî and much worse than other developed cities such as New York or Madrid.

This satellite‚òùÔ∏èüõ∞ is set to transform the way we forecast the weather around the world ‚Äì and for the first time give scientists up-to-date maps of global wind speeds. 
The European Space Agency is this week set to launch the first satellite to measure wind speeds across the entire planet. Aeolus, named after the keeper of the winds in Greek mythology, is expected to provide comprehensive maps of the Earth‚Äôs wind that will help predict the world‚Äôs weather more accurately.

The ‚Ç¨500m British-built satellite will house a sophisticated laser system called Aladin, designed to provide vertical profiles of wind speeds from the Earth‚Äôs surface up to the stratosphere at an altitude of 30km.

Currently wind information is gathered from weather balloons and tracking the ascent and descent of aeroplanes. Neither of these methods can provide the type of global image possible from satellite-based technologies.

A diplomats‚Äô diplomat, Kofi Annan, the first black African to be UN secretary-general, has died aged 80.

Photographed here in Geneva, the former UN leader and Nobel Peace Prize laureate Kofi Annan died on August 18, 2018, after a short illness.

Annan was credited with spearheading the fight against the HIV/Aids epidemic, which was particularly severe in his own continent, and for championing the Millennium Development Goals designed to prod governments into reaching minimum standards of health, education and gender equality by 2015. He became almost an embodiment of the potential and limitations of the intergovernmental body charged with fostering international co-operation and maintaining peace among nations. Annan was the first UN secretary-general to be elected from within the ranks of the organisation.

Dry weather in England is revealing ghostly traces of Neolithic monuments and Roman settlements in crop marks across the country, like this one in Eynsham, Oxfordshire.

Parched conditions are perfect for bringing out the visible evidence of historic features lying beneath farmland. Dry ground heightens changes in the colour or height of crops, revealing the presence of ancient ditches, walls or post holes.

After this year‚Äôs record-breaking heatwave, Historic England said it was looking at a ‚Äúpotential bumper year‚Äù of up to 1,000 new discoveries once its analysis of photographs is complete.

Swipe‚û°Ô∏èThe biggest companies in the US are grabbing a swelling share of revenues while workers suffer from pedestrian wage growth. And as these highly profitable businesses become more dominant, workers are capturing a smaller slice of the economic pie, some analysts say, contributing to income inequality. 
Economists increasingly agree that some sectors are becoming more dominated by a few big corporate players. A standard measure of corporate concentration ‚Äî the Herfindahl-Hirschman index ‚Äî is up 48% since 1996. There has been greater concentration in about 75% of US industries in the past two decades, according to research from academics including Gustavo Grullon of Rice University.

NASA's Parker Solar Probe to touch the Sun takes off from Cape Canaveral Air Force Station on August 12, 2018 in Florida. 
It's the first-ever mission into a part of the Sun's atmosphere called the corona. The probe will directly explore solar processes that are key to understanding and forecasting space weather events that can impact life on Earth. 
The FT's Anjana Ahuja wrote that the mission will look to answer a basic, but complex, question: how does a star work? "Specifically, why is the corona so much hotter than the solar surface a thousand miles beneath? The temperature of the corona is 2m degrees Celsius or more; the photosphere (the visible surface) underneath registers a mere 5,500C.

This is counterintuitive because the corona is further away from the nuclear furnace at the Sun‚Äôs core. It is as if, says Nicky Fox, a senior mission scientist at Johns Hopkins University in Maryland, 'you walked away from a campfire and suddenly got much hotter'." Read more at FT.com

Picture by NASA via Getty

This is what the California wildfires ‚Äì now officially the state's biggest ever ‚Äì look like from the International Space Station.

This photo from the European Space Agency shows the fires, including the Mendocino Complex fire, made up of the Ranch and River fires, has consumed close to 300,000 acres since it began on July 27.  It beats a record set further south only eight months ago. 
It is larger than the Thomas fire which started last December around Ventura and Santa Barbara in southern California, which burnt through almost 282,000 acres and caused more than $2bn worth of damage. 
Almost 4,000 firefighters and other personnel are tackling the Ranch fire, the larger of the two in Mendocino, which is still only 20 per cent contained. ‚ÄúAll fighting like hell, facing tough conditions and high temps,‚Äù Mike McGuire, state senator for California‚Äôs North Coast region, said in a Facebook post on Tuesday morning.

Three years after Dieselgate, automakers are still exploiting ‚Äòthe lawful but awful ways‚Äô to achieve the best possible scores for CO2 testing in the EU.

It had been an open secret in the industry for years that carmakers were gaming the EU lab tests in myriad ways: over-inflating tyres, taping doors, removing the sound system and turning off the air-conditioning were just a few of the methods that helped cut emissions in the lab but that were impossible to replicate on the road.

In 2014, a year before the VW diesel scandal was exposed by the US Environmental Protection Agency, one study showed that carmakers had become increasingly brazen in ‚Äúoptimising‚Äù EU tests to lower their stated carbon-dioxide emissions. From 2001 to 2013, the gap in CO2 emissions in the lab versus on the road nearly quadrupled from 8 per cent to 31 per cent, according to the International Council on Clean Transportation.

Scientists have detected the first large body of liquid water on Mars, a 20km-wide subglacial lake beneath the red planet‚Äôs ice cap seen here that they say provides a potential habitat for life.

The Italian Space Agency, which announced the news at a press conference in Rome on Wednesday, said the landmark discovery 1.5km below the planet‚Äôs surface had been made using its ground-penetrating radar technology called Marsis, which is currently onboard the European Space Agency‚Äôs Mars Express orbiter.

The existence of the Martian lake will further encourage astrobiologists‚Äô hopes that life can be found buried deep below the planet‚Äôs surface. ‚ÄúThis is a discovery of extraordinary significance, and is bound to heighten speculation about the presence of living organisms on the red planet,‚Äù said Fred Watson, a professor from the Australian Astronomical Observatory, who was not involved in the research.

Swipe to see: The head of the Donald Trump's Council of Economic Advisers is touting stronger wage growth based on a novel way of calculating it.

Kevin Hassett, the head of the White House's Council of Economic Advisers, says wages are growing just fine, if it's just calculated correctly.

With wage numbers, economists and analysts have always referred to the percentage change over the last year. Survey results pop up and down a lot from reading to reading. instead of looking at the entire last real year that actually happened, Hassett is taking the one awesome quarter we just had, and imagining a whole year of those quarters. That's how he got to 4 per cent.

Apple's Tim Cook says he's worries about spending too much time on his smartphone. It's a problem familiar to many ‚Äî especially people in the US, it seems.

Digital distraction has been blamed for a range of ills, from ruining dinner-table conversation and disrupting sleep patterns, to interfering with children‚Äôs education and contributing to an increase in anxiety and depression ‚Äî even putting young people at higher risk of suicide.

Now Silicon Valley has taken what is widely recognised as the first step towards treating addiction: admitting that it has a problem. But internet companies such as Google, Facebook and Twitter rely on winning consumers‚Äô attention to secure advertising revenues. The internet boom over the past decade, just like the dotcom bubble before it, has largely been fuelled by eyeballs ‚Äî only this time, in such huge numbers that marketers have been eager to pay to reach them.

Who has the upper hand in France and Belgium's World Cup semifinal? After their defeat of Brazil, you might be tempted to say Belgium ‚Äì but it's more complicated than that.

After Belgium took the lead in the first half, Brazil fired in 20 shots ‚Äî more than any other team at the tournament had while trailing. Three of those can be considered ‚Äúbig chances‚Äù ‚Äî opportunities with at least a one-in-five chance of scoring. This is the equal highest number that any trailing team have created.

Despite playing against a side supposed to be protecting a lead, Brazil managed more quick counters than any other team who were trailing. And yet, Brazil could only score once. That can probably be put down to bad luck, as well as a stellar performance from goalkeeper Thibaut Courtois, rather than a watertight Belgian defence.

Conclusion: even if France fall behind in their semi-final against Belgium on Tuesday night, Les Bleus should be encouraged. Steered by Martinez, Belgium appear unable to park the bus.

FT Photo Diary üì∏: Mongolian Shamans or Buu, take part in a fire ritual meant to summon spirits to mark the period of the Summer Solstice in the grasslands on outside Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. 
Banned for 70 years under Communist rule, shamanism has seen a resurgence in Mongolia since 1992, when the ancient practice became protected by the country's Constitution. Known as Tengerism, in which shamans channel ancestral spirits, it is widely regarded as Mongolia's national religion and part of its indigenous identity. Shamans, it is believed, are chosen by their ancestral spirits to serve as a bridge to the living world; a conduit to provide healing, knowledge, and advice. 
Mongolia shamanism emerged from the grasslands thousands of years before Chinggis Khan founded the Mongol empire, and has evolved with rituals in worship of nature and 'the eternal blue sky.' Modern-day shamans are more typically consulted for advice in business deals, illness, or personal difficulties. Shamans employ tools, including headdresses and mouth harps, to induce trances for the spirits to 'use' their bodies and voices. While there are no official numbers, it is believed there are over 10,000 shamans in Mongolia, and many have formed unions, organizations, and collectives.

The compelling Tory case for a second Brexit vote ‚Äì some say another referendum would be divisive, but Britain is already deeply split

The FT's Philip Stephens writes: "Theresa May‚Äôs government has perfected the art of negotiation by capitulation. Two years after the Brexit referendum the sequence ‚Äî bold demands, blunt rejection, and humiliating retreat ‚Äî is dismally familiar. There is nothing to suppose the dynamics of the end-game will be any different. The prime minister wants a deal ‚Äî and Britain desperately needs one ‚Äî so it will be on others‚Äô terms.

The result will be a Brexit that satisfies no one. Ministers can close their eyes, shrug their shoulders and stumble onwards. Everyone else should know the destination is a boulder-strewn no man‚Äôs land ‚Äî an ‚Äúout-but-in‚Äù Brexit that leaves Britain weaker, poorer and marginalised. ... There is one other option. Britain could stop and think again." Read more at FT.com

Is Thursday's Russia-Saudi Arabia match the worst World Cup game ever? It's close.

According to ‚Äúelo rankings‚Äù, which score national teams according to their results over time and are weighted against the strength of opposition they faced.

Focusing on the period from 1998, when the World Cup expanded in size from 24 to 32 teams (diluting the strength of the sides appearing at the tournament), we found that the next ‚Äúworst‚Äù opening match-up was South Africa vs Mexico from 2010. South Africa became the only hosts not to progress past the opening group stage of a World Cup.

Indeed, there have been few worse pairings in any World Cup match. New Zealand‚Äôs game against Slovakia, also in 2010, takes that ignominious title.

The Federal Reserve just lifted interest rates for the seventh time since the financial crisis.

It's also the second rate rise this year, and policymakers signalled two more increases are likely this year as policymakers gave a bullish assessment of the US economy amid accelerating growth and rapid job creation.

In a statement, the central bank dropped previous crisis-era assurances that it will keep rates below their longer-run norms. ‚ÄúThe Committee expects that further gradual increases in the target range for the federal funds rate will be consistent with sustained expansion of economic activity, strong labour market conditions, and inflation near the Committee‚Äôs symmetric 2 per cent objective over the medium term,‚Äù the Fed said, adding that risks to the outlook are roughly balanced.

This scene would have been unimaginable just months ago.

Kim Jong Un became the first North Korean leader to meet a sitting US president. After trading barbs and insults since last year, both Donald Trump and Mr Kim spoke effusively about their first meeting in Singapore. The two leaders agreed to work towards "complete denuclearisation" of the Korean peninsula. ‚ÄúThe letter that we are signing is very comprehensive, and I think both sides will be very impressed with the results,‚Äù Mr Trump said after shaking hands with the North Korean leader. 
Mr Kim said the US and North Korea would ‚Äúleave the past behind‚Äù in signing the document. ‚ÄúThe world will see a major change." But are they empty pledges? One of the challenges facing negotiators is that North Korea has remained silent on what it believes denuclearisation to mean and how far it should go.

The cabinet of Spain's new Socialist prime minister has broken barriers, with a majority of posts going to women for the first time in the country‚Äôs modern history.

Spanish media suggested the country had set a record in Europe for female participation in a government, surpassing countries such as Norway and Sweden that have established reputations for seeking gender parity.

The cabinet has 11 women and six other men, a record since Spain returned to democracy in the 1970s. In the mid-2000s, the last Socialist prime minister Jos√© Luis Rodr√≠guez Zapatero had a cabinet that was 50 per cent women.

Having its software on about 80% of smartphones has been a huge benefit for Google. But after an eight-year antitrust skirmish over what has essentially been a side-issue, the EU is finally getting ready to challenge Google on something that matters.

But coming up with changes that boost competition without hurting users will not be easy.

Donald Trump, Italy and the threat to Germany ‚Äì until now, Berlin has imported stability from its neighbours and allies.

The FT's Philip Stephens writes: "Italy is ruled by Eurosceptic populists; Poland and Hungary by authoritarian nationalists. Britain limps towards an unhappy Brexit; a new governing coalition in Spain is confronted by Catalan separatists. No one could accuse Europeans of trying to hide the continent‚Äôs stresses and strains.

Germany, of course, is the exception. Angela Merkel, that safest pair of hands, remains in charge at the chancellery, the economy is running at full employment, and federal and state governments are struggling to spend their surplus revenues. Now here‚Äôs the rub. The nation most vulnerable to the present geopolitical tumult is, well, Germany." Read more at FT.com

The iPhone is only just starting to grow up: Flat sales of smartphones mask a third industrial revolution yet to reach its peak.

The FT's John Gapper writes: "Smartphones took just a decade to reach the top of the S curve ‚Äî the classic diffusion pattern in which slow initial growth is followed by rapid take-up as word spreads and then a slowdown. But even when people are rushing out to buy the new technology, it is often too early to understand all of its potential: that realisation only comes after industries and societies adjust fully.

The era of widespread adoption ‚Äî when the technology no longer attracts as much excitement, and attention turns to the next gadget (in this case watches, home speakers and drones) ‚Äî is when things really start to happen. This was true of electricity and the rearrangement of 20th-century factories around multiple power outlets, rather than steam-driven shafts. The mobile phone has entered such a phase." Read more at FT.com

Madagascar, which supplies 80% of the world‚Äôs natural vanilla, is in the grip of a vanilla boom ‚Äì and this is one reason why.

People are saying, ‚ÄòI don‚Äôt care about growing food to feed myself. I only want to grow vanilla‚Äô,‚Äù says Eugenia Lopez, an agricultural expert with Swiss development agency Helvetas. Girls are dropping out of school to marry ‚Äúvanilla barons‚Äù, and sales of televisions, alcohol and other luxuries are high. ‚ÄúPeople are buying cars and motorbikes that they won‚Äôt even be able to fill with petrol when the price of vanilla crashes,‚Äù says Ms Lopez.

But the real price of Madagascar‚Äôs vanilla boom is a high price that hurts the ice-cream market and do little to reduce poverty on the African island.

The search advertising market may be 20 years old, but growth at the internet company has re-accelerated over the past three years. As a result, parent Alphabet ‚Äî which gets 99.5 per cent of its revenue from Google ‚Äî is expected this year to turn in its highest growth rate since 2011, even though its revenue will be nearly four times greater than it was then.

The $26bn in new business likely to be added this year is a stunning demonstration of the enduring power of Google‚Äôs core business. It also points to the health of a cash machine that has been funding the company‚Äôs next big businesses, fuelling its growth well beyond search.

Like Apple, Alphabet is closing in on a $1tn market capitalisation. Can the company hit get there? Read more at FT.com

These are the busiest airports in the world ‚Äì and that means some of them are at the forefront of using technology to speed up the frustrating parts of travelling through an airport. 
But some passenger-friendly developments are proving a challenge for airports that are losing revenues. 
In Europe, retail revenues, which make up two-fifths of European airports‚Äô non-aeronautical revenues, have been hit by the shift to online retail, falling to ‚Ç¨2.73 per passenger in 2016 from ‚Ç¨2.91 per passenger in 2010.

But it is not just retail income that is under threat from technology. Car parking revenues have suffered in recent years by the rise of ride-hailing apps, which have made travelling to the airport by taxi more affordable, and the growth in public transport services. They are also facing competition from carpooling services and online parking companies that advertise cheap spaces.

In North America, in particular, this is valuable income for airports, representing about two-fifths of non-aeronautical revenues. In Europe, car-parking income makes up about one-fifth of an airport‚Äôs non-aeronautical revenues.

Here's where we are losing ‚Äì and gaining ‚Äì forests around the world. And here's why it matters: Land clearing can cause soil erosion, which pushes sediment and fertiliser into coastal waters. And deforestation releases carbon dioxide into the atmosphere, a principal cause of climate change.

A pristine eucalyptus forest near the Great Barrier Reef has become a political battleground in a bitter dispute over land clearing in Australia, which green groups warn rivals deforestation rates in Brazil. Research shows Queensland, which has 41 per cent of Australia‚Äôs forests, is bulldozing trees at twice the rate of Brazil. 
Brazilian government statistics show 789,300 hectares of its Amazon rainforest was cleared in 2015-16, roughly double the amount of forest in Queensland, but when the number of hectares cleared is compared with the remaining woodland in each country, Queensland is far worse.

Brexit Britain has closed to foreigners ‚Äì Theresa May has chosen the harshest possible interpretation of the referendum result.

The FT's Philip Stephens writes: "There is more to Brexit than supply chains, regulations and farm subsidies. It is about the nation‚Äôs character. Membership of the EU has anchored a cosmopolitan Britain in the wider world. Does leaving portend Britain First ‚Äî a place that has had its fill of footloose elites, global corporations and migrants? Or is it to be Britain Unbound ‚Äî a country of swashbuckling free traders with their sights on the world? Brexiters have so far ducked the collision.

Qatar is one of the richest countries in the world. But can it build its way out of a blockade? 
The country is facing the most serious external threat in its four-decade history, the trade and travel embargo imposed last June by four Arab states ‚Äî Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Egypt ‚Äî over the peninsula‚Äôs alleged support for terrorism.

Now, Qatar offsetting the economic impact of the embargo by ploughing ahead with its $200bn infrastructure development programme, building roads and railways. The government also redirected $50bn from the country‚Äôs sovereign wealth fund and reserves to protect the banking sector and exchange rate.

Productivity growth has been the missing piece of the UK recovery since the 2008 financial crisis. Output per hour worked fell by 0.5 per cent during the first quarter of 2018 as hours worked rose without a matching increase in economic growth, according to figures published by the Office for National Statistics on Tuesday.

The Office for Budget Responsibility, which revised down its productivity growth forecasts last year, had said that the strong growth at the end of last year was likely due to volatile measures of hours worked rather than any change in the post-crisis trend.

How the west should judge a rising China ‚Äì advanced countries are hobbled by their inability to manage their own affairs. 
The FT's Martin Wolf writes: "As recently as 1990, advanced countries generated 78 per cent of world output at market prices and 64 per cent at purchasing power parity. For this reason, above all, westerners need to consider how those in the rising powers view the world. It is likely that China, in particular, will emerge as by far the world‚Äôs biggest economy. We need to evaluate and assess the views of those who lead it." Read more at FT.com

Israeli forces shot and killed at least 52 people along its border fence with Gaza on Monday, the Palestinian authorities said, as tens of thousands protested against the inauguration of the US embassy in Jerusalem.

More than 1,200 people were wounded, the Gaza health ministry said, as Israel deployed two extra brigades to join at least 100 snipers and other troops along the frontier with the strip. Protesters burnt tyres, sending huge plumes of black smoke into the sky, and threw stones and brandished knives at Israeli soldiers, including snipers perched on earthworks. Some groups of young men sought to breach the border fence.

At the embassy opening in Jerusalem, US officials, including Donald Trump‚Äôs daughter Ivanka and her husband Jared Kushner, mingled with Israeli prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu and other dignitaries as a musician sang a Hebrew version of ‚ÄúHallelujah‚Äù. A triumphant Netanyahu thanked the US president. ‚ÄúWe are in Jerusalem and we are here to stay,‚Äù the Israeli leader said. ‚ÄúWhat a glorious day ‚Äî remember this day. This is history.‚Äù Read the latest at FT.com

We looked at the countries with the biggest share of electronic payments and compared it with those that have high levels of consumer debt ‚Äì and found a worrying correlation.

But as the ultra-low interest rates of the developed world begin to rise, these fragile piles of debt, which electronic payments are compounding, could start to crumble.

Why was Singapore chosen as the meeting place for the coming Donald Trump-Kim Jong Un summit? ‚ÄúThe most appealing thing about Singapore is that it is a politically neutral place," Paik Hak-soon, a researcher at the Sejong Institute, told us. "It has been a preferred location for top political meetings for various reasons including security." Singapore, with its financial district pictured here, in 2015 hosted a summit between Chinese President Xi Jinping and Taiwan‚Äôs then-leader Ma Ying-jeou ‚Äî the first meeting between leaders on each side of the Taiwan Strait since the Kuomintang nationalists retreated to the island more than six decades earlier.

In addition to advanced infrastructure and summit facilities, Singapore also affords the two leaders diplomatic back-up as both nations maintain embassies in the city. 
The city also has strict public demonstration laws, making protests against either leader unlikely.

The FT's Philip Stephens writes: "Enough. America‚Äôs allies have gritted their teeth, bitten their lips and fixed their smiles. They have fawned and flattered. To no avail. Donald Trump is what he has always seemed: a nationalist bully set on bending American power to deep personal prejudices. Quitting the Iran nuclear deal is not the pursuit of a foreign policy; rather an act of boastful defiance. The president wants to show the world that he can do as he pleases. ... The first priority must be to hold together what is left of the nuclear agreement. The US may have reneged, but Europe ‚Äî and the rest of the international community ‚Äî can demonstrate that they are prepared to keep the bargain with Iran ‚Äî the lifting of sanctions in return for nuclear compliance." This moment is history in the making. 
Kim Jong Un became the first North Korean leader to set foot on South Korean soil since the 1950-53 Korean war. The summit, aimed at ending decades of conflict on the peninsula, marks a dramatic shift from the bellicose rhetoric of only a few months ago.

But not everyone is convinced that this new chapter can lead to the denuclearisation of North Korea. Few believe a formal end to the war will accomplish much without further progress towards disarmament, our reporters in Seoul write. ‚ÄúSome experts see Pyongyang‚Äôs pursuit of a peace treaty as a mere ploy to avoid discussing further progress towards denuclearisation ‚Äî a gambit it has used successfully in the past.‚Äù (Photos by Getty)
